title: How to Choose a Kitchen Rug

steps.headline: Pick the area or areas in your kitchen that need a rug.
steps.description: These often include high-traffic areas, such as under a table, in an entry way, or in front of the stove, sink or refrigerator.

steps.headline: Measure the areas that you want to cover with a rug.
steps.description: This will help you eliminate choices that are too big or too small when you begin to shop.

steps.headline: Choose the shape of your rug by measurements and furniture.
steps.description: For example, if you want it to go below a round table, choose a round rug. If you have a galley kitchen, choose a runner.

steps.headline: Decide if you need extra support for your knees or back when you cook.
steps.description: Foam and gel rugs provide a cushion for your body if you are standing on hard surfaces for long periods of time. If you need a gel rug, you may want to go directly to companies who make these, rather than looking at conventional rugs.

steps.headline: Decide if you want your rug to make a design statement or be a single color.
steps.description:
You can choose to match your cabinetry and furniture, or you can have it make a statement with a bold pattern. Darker rugs will show fewer stains and less dirt. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/3a\/Choose-a-Kitchen-Rug-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Choose-a-Kitchen-Rug-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/3a\/Choose-a-Kitchen-Rug-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Choose-a-Kitchen-Rug-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Choose a low-pile material.
steps.description: Low-pile means it is tightly woven in a flat-weave.

steps.headline: Pay attention to a rug's durability, stain-resistance and ease of cleaning.
Choose a rug with a non-slip backing.
steps.description:
A loose rug in high-traffic areas is very dangerous. Make sure the borders are very thin. You can buy adhesive strips and rug pads to help your rug stay in place. Make sure you are still able to pick up the rug in order to clean it. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/fe\/Choose-a-Kitchen-Rug-Step-8Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Choose-a-Kitchen-Rug-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/fe\/Choose-a-Kitchen-Rug-Step-8Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Choose-a-Kitchen-Rug-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

text:
Pick the area or areas in your kitchen that need a rug. These often include high-traffic areas, such as under a table, in an entry way, or in front of the stove, sink or refrigerator. Measure the areas that you want to cover with a rug. This will help you eliminate choices that are too big or too small when you begin to shop. Choose the shape of your rug by measurements and furniture. For example, if you want it to go below a round table, choose a round rug. If you have a galley kitchen, choose a runner. Decide if you need extra support for your knees or back when you cook. Foam and gel rugs provide a cushion for your body if you are standing on hard surfaces for long periods of time. If you need a gel rug, you may want to go directly to companies who make these, rather than looking at conventional rugs. Decide if you want your rug to make a design statement or be a single color. You can choose to match your cabinetry and furniture, or you can have it make a statement with a bold pattern. Darker rugs will show fewer stains and less dirt. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Choose-a-Kitchen-Rug-Step-5Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Choose-a-Kitchen-Rug-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Choose-a-Kitchen-Rug-Step-5Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Choose-a-Kitchen-Rug-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Choose a low-pile material. Low-pile means it is tightly woven in a flat-weave. Pay attention to a rug's durability, stain-resistance and ease of cleaning. A kitchen rug is susceptible to stains more than any other room. Choose a machine washable rug, if possible. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0d/Choose-a-Kitchen-Rug-Step-7Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Choose-a-Kitchen-Rug-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0d/Choose-a-Kitchen-Rug-Step-7Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Choose-a-Kitchen-Rug-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} The best stain-resistant fabrics are often nylon and wool. They can also be the softest. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2a/Choose-a-Kitchen-Rug-Step-7Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Choose-a-Kitchen-Rug-Step-7Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2a/Choose-a-Kitchen-Rug-Step-7Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Choose-a-Kitchen-Rug-Step-7Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} The easiest fabrics to clean are cotton, polypropylene and vinyl. Choose a rug with a non-slip backing. A loose rug in high-traffic areas is very dangerous. Make sure the borders are very thin. You can buy adhesive strips and rug pads to help your rug stay in place. Make sure you are still able to pick up the rug in order to clean it. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fe/Choose-a-Kitchen-Rug-Step-8Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Choose-a-Kitchen-Rug-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fe/Choose-a-Kitchen-Rug-Step-8Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Choose-a-Kitchen-Rug-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"}
